title: 103_hr529
content:
The Act is titled the "Mickey Leland Childhood Hunger Relief Act" and includes provisions for ensuring adequate food assistance and promoting self-sufficiency. Key sections address high shelter expenses, basic benefit levels, continuing benefits for eligible households, homeless families in transitional housing, improving children's nutrition in Puerto Rico, general assistance vendor payments, and assistance for low-income high school students. The "Mickey Leland Childhood Hunger Relief Act" includes provisions for child support disregard, vehicles for employment, simplifying food assistance, commodity distribution, and effective dates. Sec. 501 and Sec. 502 of the "Mickey Leland Childhood Hunger Relief Act" address effective dates and budget neutrality requirements. References to "the Act" are deemed to refer to the Food Stamp Act of 1977. Title I focuses on ensuring adequate food assistance, including provisions for families with high shelter expenses. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to remove the cap on excess shelter expense deductions and establish transitional caps based on location and time periods. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to remove the cap on excess shelter expense deductions and establish transitional caps based on location and time periods. Effective October 1, 1997, the monthly limits for benefits in different states and territories are specified. Effective October 1, 1997, a section of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended by removing a sentence. SEC. 102. BASIC BENEFIT LEVEL. Section 3(o) of the Act (7 U.S.C. 2012(o)) is amended to adjust the cost of a diet to reflect a percentage of the thrifty food plan cost in the preceding June, determined by the Secretary, and rounded to the nearest lower dollar increment for each household size on specific dates. On specific dates, the cost of a diet is adjusted to reflect a percentage of the thrifty food plan cost in the preceding June, determined by the Secretary, and rounded to the nearest lower dollar increment for each household size. The cost of a diet is adjusted on specific dates to reflect 105 percent of the thrifty food plan cost in the preceding June, determined by the Secretary, and rounded to the nearest lower dollar increment for each household size. SEC. 103 amends Section 8(c)(2)(B) of the Act regarding benefits to eligible households. SEC. 104 modifies Section 5(k)(2)(F) concerning housing assistance for homeless families in transitional housing. SEC. 105 adjusts funding for improving the nutritional status of children in Puerto Rico. SEC. 106 addresses households benefiting from general assistance vendor payments. SEC. 106 amends Section 5(k)(1)(B) of the Act to include housing expenses benefits for households under general assistance programs. SEC. 107 updates eligibility criteria for low-income high school students. TITLE II focuses on promoting self-sufficiency, including a child support disregard provision. TITLE II--PROMOTING SELF-SUFFICIENCY

SEC. 201. CHILD SUPPORT DISREGARD.

Amends Section 5 of the Act to include a provision where the first $50 of child support payments received each month are disregarded. Also, the first $50 of child support received if payments were made by the absent parent when due. Subsection (m) is removed.

SEC. 202. CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS TO NON-HOUSEHOLD MEMBERS. SEC. 202. Child support payments made by a household member to a non-household member shall be excluded from the household income if legally obligated. Section 5(g)(2) of the Act is amended to adjust the level set by the Secretary for financial resources, starting at $4,500 through September 30, 1993, and adjusting annually based on changes in the Consumer Price Index. Additionally, the Secretary shall exclude the value of a vehicle used to carry fuel or water from a household's financial resources if it is the primary source of fuel or water for the household. (a) Dependent Care Deduction.--Section 5(e) of the Act is amended to increase the monthly deduction to $200 for a dependent child under age 2 and $175 for any other dependent. 
(b) Reimbursements to Participants.--The reimbursement amount is increased from $25 to $75, and the criteria for exceeding the local market rate is revised. The Social Security Act is amended to exempt individuals from participation in the program if dependent care costs exceed the state agency's limit, which must be at least as high as the dependent care deduction limit. Reimbursements to state agencies are also adjusted to a maximum of $75 per participant per month and based on the applicable local market rate. TITLE III--SIMPLIFYING THE PROVISION OF FOOD ASSISTANCE

SEC. 301. Amends the household definition for households with children and others to simplify it.

SEC. 302. Amends resources of households with disabled members.

SEC. 303. Ensures adequate funding for the Food Stamp Program. SEC. 303 amends Section 18 of the Act to assure adequate funding for the Food Stamp Program. It redesignates subsections and ensures funding for commodity purchases under the Emergency Food Assistance Act of 1983. The provisions of the Act will be effective on October 1, 1993, with certain sections taking effect on July 1, 1994. The Act requires that costs be fully offset each fiscal year until 1998 for any provision to become effective.
